Engineering the coordination of Cu–Ni dual-atom catalysts to enhance the electrochemical CO2 overall splitting Yuan Zhuang Writing – original draft Resources Investigation Data curation Conceptualization Kaixuan Wei Resources Investigation Data curation Zhenxing Li Resources Methodology Hanzhang Gong Writing – review & editing Supervision Jianan Deng Software Methodology Haozhong Yuan Methodology Haoyu Lian Formal analysis Hao Zheng Software Honghao Zhao Validation Xiao Zhang Writing – review & editing Visualization ⁎ Jian Liu Writing – review & editing Supervision ⁎ State Key Laboratory of Heavy Oil Processing, China University of Petroleum (Beijing), Beijing 102249, China State Key Laboratory of Heavy Oil Processing China University of Petroleum (Beijing) Beijing 102249 China State Key Laboratory of Heavy Oil Processing, China University of Petroleum (Beijing), Beijing 102249, China ⁎ Corresponding authors. Graphical abstract A series of C/N-coordinated Cu–Ni diatomic catalysts were controllably synthesized. Among them, Cu/Ni–N2C2 showed high performance in ECR, OER and CO2 overall splitting reaction. The FECO achieved 98% and the long-term ECR stability of 110 h at −100 mA cm−2. Designing the coordination environment of heteroatoms around metal sites and optimizing the electronic structure of diatomic metal sites remain significant challenges in achieving efficient CO2 overall splitting. Herein, we report four configurations (Cu/Ni–N4C2, Cu/Ni–N2C4, Cu/Ni–N2C3 and Cu/Ni–N2C2) constructed by precise regulation of the coordination environment around bimetallic atoms. Cu/Ni–N2C2 showed high performance in electrochemical CO2 reduction (ECR) and water oxidation evolution reaction (OER). In the electrochemical CO2 overall splitting reaction, it achieved a Faraday efficiency of CO (FECO) of 98.0% at a low cell voltage of −2.9 V, significantly higher than widely reported values. Moreover, the FECO is above 90% over −2.7 to −4.1 V of cell voltages. Cu/Ni–N2C2 achieved long-term ECR stability of 110 h at −100 mA cm−2. Mechanism studies revealed that the change of coordination environment around the diatomic pairs moves the d-band center of the Ni atom closer to the Fermi level, thereby modulating the adsorption capacity of the catalysts to the reaction intermediates *COOH and *O. This work presents valuable insights into the rational design of diatomic catalysts and elucidates the intricate structure-performance relationship in advancing electrochemical CO2 overall splitting technology and energy-conversion applications. Keywords CO2 reduction Dual-atom catalysts Electrochemistry Overall CO2 splitting Structure-activity relationships Energy conversion 1 Introduction The efficient transformation of CO2 into high-value chemicals through renewable electricity can achieve the resource utilization of CO2 and decrease reliance on fossil fuels [1–3]. This process facilitates the cost-effective conversion of renewable energy into stored chemical energy, presenting significant potential application prospects [4–6]. However, the electrochemical CO2 reduction (ECR) process faces some key scientific problems [7–10]. (a) CO2 possesses highly stable molecular properties, and the activation of the CO bond needs to overcome a substantial thermodynamic barrier. (b) Due to its similar thermodynamic potential with ECR, the simultaneous occurrence of the electrolytic hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) as a competitive reaction is inevitable. (c) The product distribution of the reaction is complex, and controlling selectivity is challenging. The product generation includes an intricate proton-coupled electron transfer (PCET) process. Therefore, it is of great research value to design the catalyst structure reasonably to decrease the energy barrier of CO2 reaction, enhance the selectivity of single product and inhibit the occurrence of HER [11,12]. Meanwhile, the process can further enhance the comprehension of the formation of intermediates and electron transfer pathways in reaction [13]. In addition, the anodic reaction of ECR in the three-electrode system is the electrolytic water oxidation evolution reaction (OER), which provides the necessary H+ for CO2 reduction [14,15]. The overall splitting of the system is often ignored when evaluating the CO2 reduction performance. Simultaneous and efficient conduct of the two reactions is beneficial to reach high energy utilization efficiency and practical application value [16]. Thus, the development of economical, powerful and stable ECR and OER bifunctional catalysts holds great practical significance. Moreover, the energy-level matching of the bifunctional catalyst will affect the electron transfer transition, avoiding high electrolytic cell voltage and energy loss and waste due to poor matching [17]. This ensures better utilization of energy and catalysts for the entire cell system [18]. Because of its abundant availability of active sites and unique electronic structure, single atom catalysts (SACs) show excellent performance and stability, and have been widely applied and studied in electrocatalytic reactions [19–22]. Compared with SACs, dual atom catalysts (DACs) have complex electronic configurations and coordination structures. This compensates for the inherent deficiency of SACs, which lack intermetallic interactions [23–25]. The overlap of the electron orbitals between the bimetals regulates the d-band center [26], and the synergistic effect modulates the adsorption and desorption processes for reactants and intermediates at metal sites in electrocatalysis, greatly improving the stability and selectivity [27–29]. For example, a NiCo/NC sample reported by Pei et al. showed excellent electrocatalytic performance and kinetics for OER [30]. High performance from the robust synergistic interaction of heteroatomic metal Ni/Co sites results in the reduction of reaction energy barrier and the modulation of electronic structure. Similarly, Jiao et al. reported that the ECR activity of Fe1–Ni1–NC was significantly improved by the synergistic action of adjacent Fe and Ni diatomic pairs, far exceeding that of Fe-SACs or Ni–SACs alone [31]. In addition, Fe1–Ni1–N–C also exhibited remarkable CO selectivity and stability in Zn-CO2 batteries. Diatomic catalysts containing Ni atoms and Cu atoms have been repeatedly reported to have excellent catalytic performance in ECR [32]. It is widely recognized that the addition of Cu sites can modulate the electronic structure of Ni atoms as the active site, accelerating the formation of the key intermediate *COOH [33,34]. However, the application of DACs to electrochemical CO2 overall splitting is very limited, and the in-depth study of the reaction mechanism is not clear [35,36]. The precise construction and regulation of bimetallic sites is a key challenge. Adjusting the coordination structure around metal sites has proven to be an effective method to optimize the electronic structure, thereby reducing the free energy barrier generated by key intermediates and improving catalytic performance [37–40]. Therefore, the construction of metal sites and the surrounding coordination structures and the precise adjustment of electronic structures of DACs for the efficient catalysis of electrochemical CO2 overall splitting have great research potential and application prospects [33–35,41]. To our knowledge, the structural-performance relationship between the coordination environment of hetero diatomic centers and the catalytic performance has not been reported. In this work, we accurately constructed a range of C/N-coordinated Cu–Ni diatomic catalyst Cu/Ni–N x C y by controlling the pyrolysis conditions. Meanwhile, samples containing only Cu and Ni atoms (Ni–NC and Cu–NC) were synthesized under the same conditions. Due to the interaction of Cu and Ni atoms and the change of the coordination environment around the metal on the electronic structure of the central metal site and the center of the d-band, Cu/Ni–N2C2 shows excellent performance in ECR and OER. Notably, the FECO of Cu/Ni–N2C2 in CO2 overall splitting exceeds 90% at the cell voltage of −2.7 to −4.1 V, and its performance is much more excellent than that of reported CO2 catalyst. In-situ SEIRAS spectra revealed that diatomic site and its coordination of Cu/Ni–N2C2 promoted the formation of the key intermediate *COOH and the conversion of *COOH to *CO. The DFT studies further demonstrated that the exceptional CO2 overall splitting performance is ascribed to the fact that the interaction of Cu and Ni atoms and the change of C and N of the coordination around the diatomic centers can regulate the metal's d-band center and the surrounding electronic structure, decreasing the free energy barrier formed by the key intermediates *COOH of ECR and the key intermediates *O of OER, thus promoting the rapid progress of the reaction. 2 Experimental 2.1 Chemicals All chemicals were purchased from commercial sources and used without further purification.2-Methylimidazole (2-MeIM, 98.0%), zinc nitrate hexahydrate (Zn(NO3)2·6H2O, 99.9%), and nickel nitrate hexahydrate (Ni(NO3)2·6H2O, 99.9%) were obtained from Aladdin, China. Copper dinitrate (Cu(NO3)2, 99.9%) were obtained from Macklin, China. n-Hexane (C6H14, >99%) and Methanol anhydrous (CH3OH, 99.9%, water ≤ 50 ppm) were obtained from Innochem, China. Potassium bicarbonate (KHCO3, 99.5%) were purchased from Xilong Scientific Co., Ltd., China. Nafion (5 wt%, DuPont) and proton exchange membrane (Nafion 117, DuPont) were obtained from commercial suppliers. N2 (99.999%) and CO2 (99.999%) were provided by Beijing Analytical Instrument Company. 2.2 Catalysts preparation 2.2.1 Synthesis of zeolitic imidazolate framework-8 (ZIF-8) In a typical synthesis [42], Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (2.87 g) was dissolved in 105 mL of methanol under ultrasound for 15 min to form a homogeneous solution A; 2-methylimidazole (2.46 g) was dissolved in 45 mL of methanol with sonication for 15 min to form a clear solution B. Then, solution B was slowly injected into solution A with vigorous stirring for 24 h at room temperature, then was collected by centrifugation and rinsed twice with methanol, and finally dried in vacuum at 60 °C overnight. 2.2.2 Synthesis of Cu/Ni–NxCy To prepare the Cu/Ni–N x C y , the as-prepared ZIF-8 powder (300 mg) was ultrasonically dispersed in 30 mL of n-Hexane at room temperature for 1 h. After the uniform suspension was formed, Ni(NO3)2·6H2O and Cu(NO3)2 methanol solutions (both 25 mg·mL−1, 80 uL) were added under ultrasound at room temperature for 10 min. Next, the mixture was stirred at room temperature for 1 h. The sample was then centrifuged, washed with methanol several times, and dried overnight under vacuum at 60 °C.Then, the sample was placed in a tube furnace and pyrolyzed at 1100 °C for 3 h under an N2 atmosphere at a heating rate of 5 °C min−1. The obtained Cu/Ni–N2C2 was directly used without further post treatment. Cu/Ni–N4C2, Cu/Ni–N2C4 and Cu/Ni–N2C3 were prepared by a similar procedure as Cu/Ni–N2C2 but pyrolyzed at 900 °C for 3 h, 1000 °C for 3 h and 800 °C for 1 h, 900 °C for 1 h, 1000 °C for 1 h, respectively. 2.2.3 Synthesis of Ni–NC and Cu–NC Ni–NC and Cu–NC were prepared by a similar procedure as Cu/Ni–N2C2 but Ni(NO3)2·6H2O and Cu(NO3)2 methanol solutions (both 25 mg·mL−1, 160 uL) were added, respectively. 2.3 Characterization 2.3.1 Physical characterization Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) was collected on a smart X-ray diffractometer (D8 Focus, Bruker AXS, Germany) with Cu K α radiation (λ = 1.54178 Å). Raman spectra were recorded on a high-resolution laser confocal fiber Raman spectrometer (HORIBA EVOLVTION, HORIBA Jobinyvon, France) with a laser excitation length of 532 nm. The Cu and Ni contents of each sample was quantified by an inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometer (ICP-MS, Agilent 5110, USA). Nitrogen sorption measurements and CO2 sorption measurements were conducted at 77.15 and 298.15 K using a multi-station specific surface micropore and vapor adsorption analyzer (BELSORP MAX Ⅱ, MICROTRAC MRB, USA). Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) was acquired a field emission scanning electron microscope (FESEM, FEI Quanta 200F). Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) and high-resolution TEM were acquired on transmission electron microscope with a LaB6 Gun (Tecnai G2 Spirit TWIN and Talos F200 X, FEI, USA) at an acceleration voltage of 200 kV. Energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDS) mapping images were taken on a high-resolution transmission electron micros-cope with FEG (Talos F200X, FEI, USA). High-angle annular dark field scanning transmission electron microscopy (HAADF-STEM) measurements were taken on a transmission electron microscope with a probe corrector (JEM-ARM200F NEOARM, FEI). X-ray photoelectron spectra (XPS) was carried out by using an X-ray spectrometer (ESCALAB 250 Xi spectrometer, Thermo Scientific, USA) with Al K α as the excitation source. Solid electron paramagnetic resonance (EPR) spectra were carried out by using an Electron Paramagnetic Resonance Spectrometer (EMXplus, Bruker, Germany). 2.3.2 In-situ ATR-SEIRAS measurements The in-situ attenuated total reflection-surface-enhanced IR absorption spectroscopy (ATR-SEIRAS) spectroscopy experiments were conducted in a modified electrochemical cell that integrated into a Nicolet 6700 Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FTIR) spectrometer equipped with mercury-cadmium-telluride (MCT) detector cooled by liquid nitrogen. The catalysts ink was dropped on a germanium (Ge) ATR crystal deposited with Au film. Pt foil and Ag/AgCl (saturated KCl) were used as counter electrode and reference electrode. Each spectrum was collected with a time resolution of 42 s. Before the test, the initial state with open circuit was scanned for a background. All applied potentials were converted to the reversible hydrogen electrode (RHE). 2.3.3 XAS measurements The X-ray adsorption spectroscopy (XAFS) measurements were performed using a modified flow cell at BL14W1 station in Beijing Synchrotron Radiation Facility (BSRF) and Singapore Synchrotron Light Source (SSLS) centers. The storage ring was works at 2.5 GeV with an average electron current of 200 mA in SSRF and SSLS. Using Si (111) double-crystal monochromator and ionization chamber, the data was collected in a transmission mode for referenced samples (Ni foils, NiO, Cu foils, CuO), and fluorescence mode for all prepared catalysts. All spectra were collected under ambient conditions. The acquired extended X-ray absorption fine structure (EXAFS) data were processed according to the standard procedures using the ATHENA module implemented in the IFEFFIT software packages [43,44]. The acquired EXAFS data were processed according to the standard procedures using the Athena and Artemis implemented in the IFEFFIT software packages. The fitting detail is described below. The acquired EXAFS data were processed according to the standard procedures using the ATHENA module implemented in the IFEFFIT software packages. The EXAFS spectra were obtained by subtracting the post-edge background from the overall absorption and then normalizing with respect to the edge-jump step. Subsequently, the χ(k) data were Fourier transformed to real (R) space using a hanning windows (d k = 1.0 Å−1) to separate the EXAFS contributions from different coordination shells. To obtain the quantitative structural parameters around central atoms, least-squares curve parameter fitting was performed using the ARTEMIS module of IFEFFIT software packages. The Ni and Cu K-edge theoretical X-ray absorption near-edge structure (XANES) calculations were carried out with the FDMNES code in the framework of real-space full multiple-scattering (FMS) scheme using Muffin-tin approximation for the potential [45]. 2.4 Electrochemical measurements Electrochemical measurements were performed in both H-type cell and flow cell using an electrochemical station (CHI660E). H-type cell was separated by a proton exchange membrane (Nafion 117, Dupont) [46]. Each compartment contained 30 mL 0.5 M KHCO3 electrolyte. Pt foil and Ag/AgCl (saturated KCl) were used as counter electrode and reference electrode. Flow cell was separated by an anion exchange membrane (FAA-3-PK-130, Fumasep) [47]. Each compartment contained 0.5 M KOH electrolyte. Pt foil and Ag/AgCl (saturated KCl) were used as counter electrode and reference electrode. Linear sweep voltammetry (LSV) measurements were carried out with a scan rate of 5 mV s−1 in the potential ranges without iR compensation. The electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) experiments were carried out by applying an AC voltage with 30 mV amplitude in a frequency range from 105 to 0.01 Hz. The electrochemical double-layer capacitance (C dl) was calculated by the CV method at different scan rates (10–80 mV s−1) within a non-faradic potential range (0.20–0.40 V vs. RHE). 2.4.1 Preparation of the working electrode The catalyst ink was prepared by dispersing 5 mg in the mixture of 470 μL isopropyl alcohol and 30 μL Nafion solution. Then, an aliquot of catalyst ink was dropped onto a carbon fiber paper or a glassy carbon electrode to make the loading amount of 1.0 mg cm−2 and allowed to dry under the infrared heat lamp. A CO2 saturated electrolyte was prepared by purging CO2 gas into liquid electrolyte for at least 30 min to remove air. All the electrochemical measurements were carried out at 25 °C. 2.4.2 Gas product analysis The catalytic product in gaseous phase of the reaction system was analyzed by gas chromatography (GC-2014+ATF, 230C, Shimadzu, Japan) equipped with two automated gas sampling valves, which contain a thermal conductivity detector (TCD) and a flame ionization detector (FID). The catalytic product in liquid phase of the reaction system was analyzed by using a Bruker AVANCE III HD 400 MHz NMR spectrometer. 2.4.3 Nernst equation All applied potentials were measured at 25 °C versus the reference electrode Ag/AgCl (saturated KCl) reference electrode, which were converted to those versus RHE based on the Nernst equation E v s . R H E = E v s . Ag / AgCl + 0.059 × p H + 0.197 2.4.4 Faradaic efficiency The Faradaic efficiency (FE) of each gaseous product was calculated using the following equation FE g a s p r o d u c t = Q g a s Q t o t a l × 100 % = N × F × V × v × P 0 R × T × I × 60 × 100 % where N is electron transfer number (which is 2 for CO); F is Faradaic constant (96485C mol−1); V is gas flow rate measured by a flow meter at the exit of the cell at room temperature under ambient pressure (mL min−1); v is volume concentration of gas products (CO or H2) from GC (νol%); I is cell current at steady state recorded by electrochemical workstation (C s−1). 2.4.5 Tafel slope The Tafel slope for ECR was calculated using the following equation η = b l o g j j 0 where η is the overpotential (mV) between the applied potential to the standard potential; b is the Tafel slope (mV dec−1); j is current density (mA cm−2); j 0 is exchange current density (mA cm−2). 2.4.6 Turnover frequency (TOF) The turnover frequency (TOF, h−1) of the samples was calculated based on the following equation T O F = I c o / n F m c a t a l y s t w / M t where I co is partial current for certain product (A); n is the number of electron transferred for product formation; F is the Faradaic constant (96485C mol−1); m catal y st is catalyst mass in the electrode (g); w is the active metal loading in the catalyst; M is atomic mass of active metal; t is 3600 s. 2.5 DFT calculations The spin-polarized density functional theory (DFT) calculations were performed by using the Vienna Ab initio Simulation Package (VASP) [48–51]. The exchange–correlation functional adopted the expression of Perdew-Burke Ernzerhof (PBE) in the generalized gradient approximation (GGA) method [52]. Meanwhile, the Grimme method (DFT-D3) was introduced to consider the weak van der Waals interactions [53]. A 5 × 5 × 1 Monkhorst-Pack grid was used for sampling the Brillouin zones at structure optimization [54]. The ion–electron interactions were described by the projector augmented wave (PAW) method. The solution of a single electron wavefunction at the ground state utilized the PAW method in a real space with a cutoff energy of 450 eV for the planewave basis set. The iterative convergence of energy and force was 10−6 eV and 0.01 eV Å−1, respectively. A 15 Å lattice constant along the z-axis was set to avoid the layer image coupling caused by the periodic model. Only one Cu and one Ni atoms were introduced into each dual-metal site model. The reversible hydrogen electrode was used as the reference to calculate the free energy of adsorbed intermediates, for which the free energy of a pair of proton and electron (H+ + e–) is calculated as the free energy of 1/2 H2 [55–57]. Gibbs free energy was calculated using zero-point energy and thermal corrections. The free energy change ΔG of any chemical species can be calculated as Δ G = Δ E + Δ E Z P E - T Δ S + ∫ C p d T where ΔE is the reaction energy, ΔE ZPE is the difference in the zero-point energy between reactants and products, TΔS and ∫C p dT are the contributions of entropic and enthalpic energy at room temperature (T = 298.15 K). The effects of applied electrode potential (U) on the free energy of the electron transfer steps. The limiting potential (U L) is defined as the maximum free energy change (ΔG ma x ) among all elementary steps along the most favorable pathway using the relation U L = −ΔG ma x /e. The ECR pathway involved two proton-electron transfers and a chemical reaction with two intermediates. Denoting the active site for adsorption as *, the ECR path is * + CO2 + H+ + e− → *COOH *COOH + H+ + e− → *CO + H2O *CO → * + CO (g) The OER pathway involved four proton-electron transfers and a chemical oxidation with three intermediates. Denoting the active site for adsorption as *, the OER path is * + H2O → *OH + H+ + e− *OH → *O + H+ + e− *O + OH− → *OOH + e− *OOH → * + O2 (g) + H+ + e− The competitive HER pathway is * + H+ + e− → *H 2*H→ * + H2 (g) 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Synthesis and characterization A series of atomic and diatomic catalysts were synthesized through high-temperature pyrolysis of ZIF-8 precursors. Several methods for synthesizing ZIF-8 have been reported with the properties of the resulting ZIF-8 varying according to the method chosen, including solvothermal, natural sedimentation and microwave-assisted, etc. [58]. Because of the mild synthesis conditions and regular morphology and relatively large specific surface area [59], ZIF-8 was prepared by natural sedimentation method using methanol as solvent in this work. Then Cu–ZIF, Ni/ZIF and Cu/Ni–ZIF precursors were obtained by adsorption, and then pyrolyzed in an inert atmosphere. The Zn atom in the precursor evaporated at high temperature, while carbonization of non-metallic components and volatilization of some organic fragments occurred in the materials. By carefully controlling the temperature and time of pyrolysis, the coordination atoms around Cu and Ni were changed. As the temperature increases, part of the N coordination around the metal was converted to C coordination. At higher temperatures, the coordination atoms around the metal will leave and the metal coordination number will decrease. According to the coordination number of C and N atoms around the diatomic centers, the four structures are named Cu/Ni–N4C2, Cu/Ni–N2C4, Cu/Ni–N2C3 and Cu/Ni–N2C2, respectively (Scheme 1 ). Under the same conditions of the synthesis of Cu/Ni–N2C2, the Cu and Ni monoatomic structures were named Ni–NC and Cu–NC, respectively. X-ray diffraction (XRD) spectra reveal that the precursor possesses a high crystal structure before pyrolysis (Fig. S1). The peak location is consistent with the standard spectra of ZIF-8 and is attributed to the incorporation of trace metals Cu and Ni without changing the original crystal structure. After pyrolysis, broad peaks attributed to (002) and (101) planes of graphitic carbon appeared in all six samples at 20°–30° and 40°–50° respectively (Fig. S2), indicating that the crystallinity of the samples was destroyed by high temperature [33]. Moreover, the absence of characteristic peaks of Ni and Cu indicates that they are well dispersed, and there is no obvious accumulation of metal or metal oxides. This is further confirmed by the absence of obvious diffraction arcs in two-dimensional wide-angle X-ray diffraction (2D-WAXD) patterns (Fig. S3). SEM and TEM images demonstrate that the sample was consistent with the state before pyrolysis in a regular dodecahedral structure with a particle size of approximately 500 nm (Fig. 1 a, Figs. S4 and S5). There is no obvious collapse and deformation of the sample after high temperature. The corresponding selected area electron diffraction (SAED) pattern in the illustration reveals the typical ring characteristic of disordered carbon, and the absence of metal diffraction points proves that the sample has no accumulation of metal clusters (Fig. 1a, Fig. S6). To prove the presence of Cu and Ni in atomic pairs, the samples were further analyzed by the aberration-corrected HAADF-STEM. Consistently, no significant nanoparticles were observed on the HAADF-STEM images, and a considerable quantity of well-dispersed pairs of bright spots (marked by red rectangular boxes) were observed after magnification (Fig. 1b). We randomly selected three distant bright spots for distance measurement, all of which are between 2.5–2.6 Å, which implies the coupling between the diatomic pairs on account of the substantial electron interaction between Cu and Ni (Fig. 1c). In addition, weak peaks of Cu and Ni appear on the electron energy loss spectrum (EELS), which is due to the limitation of the low content of Cu and Ni atoms, but also serves as additional evidence for the existence of diatomic pairs (Fig. 1d). The HAADF-STEM of Cu–NC and Ni–NC is the presence of dispersed bright spots rather than bright spot pairs, indicating that the metal sites on Cu–NC and Ni–NC are atomically dispersed, also further proving the existence of Cu–Ni diatomic pairs on Cu/Ni–N2C2 (Fig. S7). The existence of Cu–Ni diatom and the uniform distribution of metallic elements on nitrogen-doped carbon support is also demonstrated by EDS elemental mapping images (Fig. 1e, Fig. S8). The peaks of the D band (1350 cm−1) and the G band (1580 cm−1) in the Raman spectra are resulted from the lattice defects of carbon and the sp 2 hybridization of carbon atoms, respectively (Fig. S9). The abundant defect structure is favorable for the dispersion and anchoring of metal atoms. The values of I D/I G of all samples were close to 1, and the values of I D/I G gradually decreased with the transformation of N-coordinated structure to C-coordinated structure and the decrease of coordination number. It seems to be contradictory to the fact that higher temperatures increase defective structures in the samples. We speculate that it may be due to the high temperatures deepen the degree of graphitization [60]. On the other hand, graphitization of the samples is more conducive to the electrical conductivity of the samples. And due to the same pyrolysis conditions, the values of I D/I G of Cu–NC, Ni–NC and Cu/Ni–N2C2 are very similar. Nitrogen adsorption and desorption isotherms show Langmuir type I, type Ⅳ, and hysteresis loops, indicating that the samples have abundant micropores and mesoporous structures, and the micropores inherit the pore structure of the precursor of ZIF (Figs. S10 and S11). Simultaneously, the volatilization of Zn atoms and a small part of the organic ligands formed larger micropores and a few mesoporous pores due to high temperature pyrolysis. The six samples have similar BET surface areas and pore structure (Table S1). With the decrease of N coordination numbers, both the BET surface areas and pore volume increased. Cu/Ni–N2C2 has a specific surface area of up to 1297.9 cm2 g−1, with better ability to improve mass transfer. XPS was employed to analyze the chemical composition and state of the materials. In the spectrum of N 1s, the results can be deconvoluted into five typical peaks [34], which are pyridinic N (397.5 eV), metal-bonded N (398.5 eV), pyrrolic N (399.7 eV), graphitic N (401.0 eV) and oxidized N (403.0 eV) (Fig. S12). The peaks at 398.5 eV are attributed to the porphyrin-like metal-bonded N coordination configuration, indicating that Cu and Ni exist on the carbon support in the N-coordinated form. The N content of Cu/Ni–N4C2 are the highest, gradually decreasing with the increase in pyrolysis temperature (Table S2). This decrease is attributed to the volatilization of organic fragments at high temperatures, consistent with the idea that the N coordination number decreases. In the spectrum of C 1s [38], the results are deconvoluted into three typical peaks, which are CO (288.9 eV), CN (285.3 eV), CCC (284.5 eV) (Fig. S13). The absence of metal-bonded (M−C) is due to the fact that the content of metal is too small to cause the signal of M−C to exceed the detection limit. In the spectrum of Cu 2p and Ni 2p, the peak positions of Cu 2p 3/2 and Ni 2p 3/2 are between Cu0/Ni0–Cu2+/Ni2+, revealing the characteristic of Cu δ +/Ni δ +(0 < δ < 2) (Figs. S14 and S15). Compared with the Cu 2p 3/2 and Ni 2p 3/2 peaks of Cu/Ni–N2C2, they shift in the direction of high binding energy and low binding energy respectively at Ni–NC and Cu–NC. These data suggested the Ni atom adjacent to Cu are more negatively charged and the electron interactions between the Cu and Ni atoms existed in Cu/Ni–N2C2, resulting in a modified electronic structure [33,34]. As the transformation from N-coordinated structure to C-coordinated structure and the decrease in coordination numbers occur, the binding energy shifts in a lower direction. Subjecting the sample to a more intense pyrolysis process at elevated temperatures would lead to more reduction degree of metal centers, potentially attributed to electron donation from the intrinsic carbon source. The change of coordination environment affects the interaction between metals and N/C, resulting in changes in electronic structure. Furthermore, the Gibbs free energy of intermediate generation is optimized in electrocatalytic inversion. The Cu and Ni content assessed through inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry (ICP-MS) were similar (Table S3). In addition, the signal quality is too low due to the low content of Cu atoms in the samples, but the peak at 917.8 eV attributed to Cu2+ can still be observed in Cu LMM XPS spectra (Fig. S16) [61]. The atomic environment and coordination structure of Cu and Ni atoms were analyzed in detail by X-ray absorption spectroscopy (XAS). In the Ni K-edge XANES spectra obtained by normalization, the absorption edges of the all catalysts are situated between Ni foil and NiO (Fig. 2 a). This indicates that the states of Ni in the samples are between 0 and +2. Notably, the positions of the absorption edges of the samples, Cu/Ni–N4C2, Cu/Ni–N2C4, Cu/Ni–N2C3 Cu/Ni–N2C2 and Ni–CN, gradually moved in the direction of higher energy, implying that the valence states of Ni in the samples were similar but not identical, and gradually increased between 0 and +2. This result in line with the above XPS fitting. The Fourier transforms (FTs) of the extended X-ray absorption fine structure (EXAFS) spectra of Ni K-edge for samples do not show peaks attributed to NiNi bonds at 2.47 Å, excluding the presence of Ni nanoparticles [31]. This is the strongest evidence that Ni is present as a single atom in all samples. The peaks ascribed to NiN and NiC were fitted at 1.87 and 2.07 Å respectively for the samples [41], which were also consistent with the fitting results of XPS (Fig. 2b, c, Figs. S17–S21). Similarly, information from Cu K-edge XANES spectra further provides the coordination structures of the catalysts (Fig. 2d). The absorption edges of the samples are situated between Cu foil and CuO, indicating that the states of Cu in the catalysts is between 0 and +2, and the positions of the samples are different to some extent (Fig. 2e). The FTs of the Cu K-edge EXAFS spectra for catalysts did not show peaks ascribed to CuCu bonds at 2.53 Å, indicating that Cu clusters is absent [29], and peaks attributed to CuN and CuC were also fitted (Fig. 2f, Figs. S22–S26). Significantly, the peak of CuNi bond was not fitted in the FTs of the EXAFS spectra. This indicates that there is no bonding between Cu and Ni, but the distance between the two atoms in the above HAADF-STEM and EELS results indicates that Cu and Ni atoms are in adjacent positions. This evidence confirms a powerful interplay between Cu atom and Ni atom [34]. From the fitting results of EXAFS, it can be determined that the coordination numbers of Ni with C and N in Cu/Ni–N2C2 are 0.9 and 2.1, and the coordination numbers of Cu with C and N are 0.9 and 1.8, respectively (Tables S4 and S5). The coordination number results for Cu/Ni–N4C2, Cu/Ni–N2C4, Cu/Ni–N2C3, Cu–NC and Ni–NC were obtained using the same method. Combined with the above results, six models Cu/Ni–N x C y , Cu–NC and Ni–NC are constructed. Considering that XANES spectroscopy possesses a more sensitive identification of the atomic configuration, we performed comparison between experimentally and theoretically simulated Ni and Cu K-edge XANES spectra of the structures using the FDMNES code. The simulated XANES profile based on the proposed Cu/Ni–N x C y , Ni–NC and Cu–NC structures exhibited similar features to the experimental XANES results (Figs. S27–S31). Taking all these results together, well-defined structures of Cu/Ni–N x C y , Ni–NC and Cu–NC were successfully constructed. In addition, solid EPR spectra indicated that with the increase of pyrolysis temperature, more N-vacancy existed in the samples (Fig. S32). The N-vacancy proved the departure of N-containing fragments around the metal at most in Cu/Ni–N2C2, which matched the fitting results of EXAFS. The above results prove that the coordination environment of atomic and diatomic materials can be accurately determined at from the atomic level through regulating the pyrolysis temperature and pyrolysis time. The change of C and N coordination around the metal and the appearance of coordination vacancies is realized. 3.2 Electrocatalytic performance 3.2.1 ECR and OER performance The performance of ECR process was studied in a three-electrode system. The LSV curves tests were performed in CO2 atmospheres in a H-cell (Fig. 3 a, Fig. S33). Cu/Ni–N2C2 has the more positive onset potential and the greater current density than other three samples over a wide potential range (0 to −1.2 V vs RHE), indicating that the active site in Cu/Ni–N2C2 has the best activation ability for CO2 molecules. At −1.2 V vs RHE, the current density of Cu/Ni–N2C2 is as high as 1.72, 2.55, 1.28, 1.34, 1.07 times that of Cu/Ni–N4C2, Cu/Ni–N2C4, Cu/Ni–N2C3, Ni–NC and Cu–C, respectively. To further analyze the reduction product, controlled potential electrolysis of CO2 was performed at various potentials in a flow cell. The analysis of the products was conducted through online gas chromatography (GC). The main products were H2 and CO, and no liquid products were detected by 1H nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR) spectroscopy (Fig. S34). The FECO is analyzed over a broad potential span from −0.4 to −1.1 V (Fig. 3b, Figs. S35 and S36). FECO of Cu/Ni–N2C2 is greater than 95% in the region from −0.4 to −0.8 V. The FECO achieves a maximum of nearly 100% (98.5%) at −0.6 V. Obviously, the FECO of samples varies with effects of Cu/Ni diatomic sites and the change of N coordination environment. In the measured potential window, the FECO of Cu/Ni–N2C2 is greater than that of the other samples. FECO of Cu/Ni–N2C2 (98.5% at −0.6 V vs RHE) is greater than Cu–NC (80.6% at −0.5 V vs RHE) and Ni–NC (77.4% at −0.4 V vs RHE). And the maximum CO Faraday efficiency of the four diatomic samples was Cu/Ni–N2C2 (98.4% at −0.6 V vs RHE) > Cu/Ni–N2C3 (96.9% at −0.4 V vs RHE) > Cu/Ni–N4C2 (81.7% at −0.4 V vs RHE) > Cu/Ni–N2C4 (74.8% at −0.4 V vs RHE). Interestingly, the CO partial current density (j CO) of Cu/Ni–N2C2 increased with an increasing negative potential in a flow cell, but the other samples showed little change in j CO in the tested potential window (Fig. 3c, Fig. S37). This phenomenon is speculated to be the unique active site structure of Cu/Ni–N2C2, which accelerates the electron transport of ECR process and makes its performance better. Cu/Ni–N2C2 has the minimum Tafel slope (124.92 mV dec−1) with Cu/Ni–N4C2 (211.8 mV dec−1), Cu/Ni–N2C4 (252.2 mV dec−1), Cu/Ni–N2C3 (142.48 mV dec−1), Ni–NC (185.82 mV dec−1) and Cu–NC (141.66 mV dec−1), which reveals that the first electron transfer step (CO2→*COOH) is the rate-limiting step of ECR, and proves that Cu/Ni–N2C2 has the best CO2 reduction kinetics (Fig. S38). Cyclic voltammetry (CV) method was used to evaluate the electrochemical active surface area (ECSA) of the samples in the non-polarized region. It was found that the active ECSA value of Cu/Ni–N2C2 was maximum, indicating that the number of active sites of Cu/Ni–N2C2 was the highest (Figs. S39 and S40). Due to the different content of active metal sites in different samples, we further evaluated the turnover frequency (TOF, h−1) and ECSA-normalized CO partial current density of Cu/Ni–N2C2, Cu–NC and Ni–NC, and the results showed that Cu/Ni–N2C2 possesses a larger TOF and ECSA-normalized CO partial current density, indicating a higher intrinsic activity (Figs. S41 and S42). The excellent performance of Cu/Ni–N2C2 came from the optimization of the diatomic sites and the coordination structure around Cu and Ni. In the EIS Nyquist plots (Fig. S43), Cu/Ni–N2C2 shows the minimum radius of the arc, indicating that the interface charge transfer resistance gradually decreases with the formation of Cu/Ni diatomic sites and the transformation of the N coordination environment around Cu and Ni, further confirming that Cu/Ni–N2C2 has the fastest charge transfer speed. At −100 mA cm−2, the long-term stability of Cu/Ni–N2C2 continuous electrolysis for 110 h was confirmed, the potential and CO selectivity did not decrease in an obvious way, and FECO was always stable at more than 96% (Fig. 3d, Fig. S44). Based on the above analysis, Cu/Ni–N2C2 has demonstrated excellent electrocatalytic performance, selectivity and stability for ECR, which is superior to or comparable to other advanced catalysts [37,40,41,62,63]. The adsorption capacity of CO2 is an important evaluation factor for the ECR reaction. The CO2 absorption isotherm diagram at room temperature shows that the adsorption capacity of Cu/Ni–N2C2 is stronger than that of Cu/Ni–N4C2, Cu/Ni–N2C4, Cu/Ni–N2C3, Cu–NC and Ni–NC, and the high CO2 concentration at the active site is very likely to be one of the favorable factors to promote the ECR (Fig. S45). For OER performance at 0.5 M KHCO3 aq, the overpotential of Cu/Ni–N2C2 at a current density of 10 mA cm−2 is only 540 mV, which is better than other samples and Pt foil (Fig. 3e, Fig. S46). The data indicates that the formation of Cu/Ni diatomic sites and the adjustment of C/N coordination environment around Cu and Ni can promote the performance of OER. It is important to note, that the OER performance of the samples is better than that of Pt used in the traditional ECR electrode. Furthermore, we assessed the long-term stability of Cu/Ni–N2C2 continuous electrolysis for 55 h (Fig. S47). The absence of any obvious deactivation of the sample proves that Cu/Ni–N2C2 has excellent stability for OER. The excellent performance for OER is also confirmed by the fact that Cu/Ni–N2C2 has a lower Tafel slope (127.67 mV dec−1) than Cu/Ni–N4C2 (261.34 mV dec−1), Cu/Ni–N2C4 (320.08 mV dec−1), Cu/Ni–N2C3 (188.75 mV dec−1), Ni–NC (192.73 mV dec−1), Cu–NC (187.06 mV dec−1) and Pt foil (363.68 mV dec−1) (Fig. S48). 3.2.2 CO2 overall splitting performance Encouraged by the above excellent OER performance and ECR performance, we evaluated the performance of CO2 overall splitting in H-cell and flow cell. A typical CO2 overall splitting electrochemical cell driven by the potentiostat contains bifunctional samples as cathode for CO2 reduction to CO and anode for H2O oxidation to oxygen gas simultaneously. The reference electrode and the opposite electrode are connected to the anode side, and the working electrode is linked to the cathode side. Compared with Cu/Ni–N4C2, Cu/Ni–N2C4, Cu/Ni–N2C3, Ni–NC and Cu–NC, Cu/Ni–N2C2 has a maximum current density in the voltage range of −1.0 to −4.7 V, which is consistent with the performance results of ECR and OER (Fig. 3f, Fig. S49). We compared LSV scan curves of Cu/Ni–N2C2||Cu/Ni–N2C2 (Cu/Ni–N2C2 for the anode) and Cu/Ni–N2C2||Pt (Pt for the anode), among which Pt foil is the most commonly used cathode material in ECR [40,64,65]. Interestingly, the current density of Cu/Ni–N2C2 as the anode for the CO2 overall splitting reaction is 2.12 times that of Pt as the anode at the cell voltage. This indicates that the sample can accelerate the transfer of electrons to the cathode ECR better than Pt, which is due to the better OER performance of the sample. It is also possible that the energy level matching between Cu/Ni–N2C2 and Cu/Ni–N2C2 is stronger than that between the sample and Pt. Impressively, the FECO of Cu/Ni–N2C2 as a bifunctional catalyst is higher than 90% at −2.7 to −4.1 V, and up to 98% at −2.7 V (Fig. 3g, Figs. S50 and S51). ECR dominates over a wide range of potential. FECO of Cu/Ni–N2C2 (98.0%) is greater than Cu–NC (85.9%) and Ni–NC (82.9%). Consistently, the FECOma x sequence of the four samples were Cu/Ni–N2C2 (98.0%) > Cu/Ni–N2C3 (92.7%) > Cu/Ni–N4C2 (76.7%) > Cu/Ni–N2C4 (61.0%). The FECO of continuous electrolysis for 48 h at 100 mA cm−2 is still stable at about 95%, and the cell voltage does not fluctuate greatly (Fig. 3h, Fig. S52). This is due to the high stability of the sample in both the ECR and OER processes, indicating that the application of the samples as bifunctional catalysts for the CO2 overall splitting reaction has a strong application. Cu/Ni–N2C2 reached a current density of 49.6 mA cm−2 with a FECO of 97.7% at a low cell voltage of −3.3 V in H-cell, significantly higher than widely reported values. (Fig. 3i) [16,18,66–69]. In order to analyze the change of metal sites and its structural stability after reaction as a bifunctional catalyst, the cathode and anode samples were characterized after electrochemical stability testing. The absence of characteristic peaks of Ni and Cu in XRD spectra and the absence of metal diffraction points in SAED pattern of high resolution-TEM reveal that the metal sites of the sample remained highly dispersed after electrochemical CO2 overall splitting (Figs. S53 and S54). The value of I D/I G did not change obviously after reaction compared with before reaction, and the bonding type and proportion of N and C in the C 1s and N 1s of XPS spectra remained similar (Figs. S55 and S56). For any changes in metal sites in the sample after electrochemical testing, there were no shift for the Cu 2p peaks and Ni 2p peaks (Fig. S57). This proves that the valence state of the metal has not changed significantly. The basic overlap of the absorption edges of the samples from Cu K-edge and Ni K-edge XANES spectra further proves that the metal valence state does not change significantly after the cathode and anode testing (Fig. S58). In order to further analyze the stability of the coordination structure of the sample before and after reaction, we have fitted the EXAFS spectra in R space of the samples. Interestingly, the coordination numbers of Ni and Cu with C and N in Cu/Ni–N2C2 increased after cathode and anode testing, but the coordination numbers of N and C remained close to 2 and 1, respectively (Tables S6 and S7). We speculate that a small number of reactants or intermediates may not be completely desorbed at the surface, but the coordination environment of the catalyst does not change before and after the cathode and anode tests, which further proves the structural stability of the material. The above results indicate that there is greater application value and practical significance to use the sample as a bifunctional catalyst in the CO2 overall splitting reaction of the two electrodes. 3.3 Mechanisms 3.3.1 The in-situ ATR-SEIRAS spectra analysis In order to comprehend the origin of the superior ECR activity of Cu/Ni–N2C2, in-situ attenuated total reflection surface-enhanced infrared absorption spectroscopy (ATR-SEIRAS) was performed to monitor and analyze the reaction intermediates in CO2-saturated KHCO3 aq (Fig. 4 a, Fig. S59). In in-situ ATR-SEIRAS spectra, it can detect multiple absorption bands between 1100 and 2400 cm−1. The peak at 1255 cm−1 is attributed to COH stretch of the key intermediate *COOH on the sample surface [65]. The positive peaks at 1445 cm−1 are attributed to CO3 2− derived from KHCO3 aq [33,70], and the positive peak near 1630 cm−1 is assigned to the stretching vibrations of adsorbed H2O molecules on the surface [71,72]. It is worth noting that peaks at 1890–1940 cm−1 were attributed to the vibration feature of bridge-bonded *CO (*COB) converted from *COOH on the Cu/NiN x C y [73]. While peaks at 2080–2100 cm−1were attributed to the vibration feature of linearly bonded *CO (*COL) converted from *COOH on the CuNC and NiNC [74]. The redshift of the peak in a reasonable range indicates that the adsorption strength of the substance is weakened, confirming that *CO produces CO molecules on the surface desorption during ECR process [75]. The negative peak at 2355 cm−1 represents the consumption of CO2 species in the solution [76]. The consumption or reduction of an intermediate corresponds to a negative peak, and the production or increase of an intermediate corresponds to a positive peak. With the accumulation of time, CO2 and CO3 2− are always in a state of consumption, and the negative peak intensity of CO2 decreases with the electrolytic time due to the continuous replenishment of external CO2 gas. It is speculated that the continuous consumption of CO2 in the solution also leads to the improvement of the solubility of CO2 gas in the electrolyte. Meanwhile, the activation and dissociation of water molecules on is a necessary process to provide protons for the ECR. And the gradual enhancement of the positive peak at 1255 cm−1 indicates that CO2 molecules can be protonated rapidly into *COOH intermediates. Additionally, the peak of *CO also increased gradually, indicating that the conversion of *COOH material to *CO species occurred rapidly on the surface. Therefore, the mechanism of ECR on catalyst surface was proposed: CO2 molecules promptly undergo protonation upon adsorption on the sample surface, forming the key intermediate *COOH. Subsequently, *COOH undergoes further transformation into *CO, and ultimately, the desorption of *CO yields the desired product, carbon monoxide gas. Similarly, in in-situ ATR-SEIRAS spectra for OER, it can detect multiple absorption bands between 1000 and 1500 cm−1 (Fig. 4b, Fig. S60). The positive peak at 1248 and 1115 cm−1 are ascribed to the OO stretching mode of *OOH and the stretching vibration of the O2 − derived from *OOH, respectively [77,78]. The positive peak at 1420 cm−1 is ascribed to the adsorbed oxygen molecules formed on the catalyst surface [79]. As the electrolysis time extended, there was a slight enhancement in the peak strength of OER, revealing that the excellent catalytic activity of the OER on the sample was promoted by the formation of intermediates. 3.3.2 The density functional theory calculations To gain further insights into the essential mechanism of Cu/Ni diatomic catalyst metal sites and coordination environment and the CO2 overall splitting performance, the density functional theory (DFT) calculations were then performed. Based on EXAFS spectra fitting results, six structural models are constructed respectively (Fig. S61). Moreover, the adsorption models of the intermediates of the elementary reaction steps in the ECR, OER and the side reaction HER were optimized. Theoretically, the Ni atoms in the Cu/Ni–N x C y structure have greater electronegativity and higher charge density than the Cu atoms, so the reactants are preferentially and stably adsorbed at the Ni site. However, there is the possibility of intermediate bridge adsorption in diatomic materials. Therefore, the Gibbs free energy (ΔG) of the formation of the intermediate on Cu, Ni and bridge sites were compared (Figs. S62-S64). In addition to *CO, ΔG of intermediates generated at Ni site is always lower than that generated at Cu site and bridge site, indicating that the energy barrier to be overcome when the reaction occurs at Ni site is the smallest. The ΔG of *CO on the bridge site is lower than that on Cu and Ni site, indicating that the bridge adsorption of CO is more stable. This explains the appearance of the bridge adsorption peak of CO in the in situ ATR-SEIRAS spectra. Moreover, the generation of *CO is not the rate-limiting step in ECR. Therefore, the active site of the reaction was mainly recognized to be the Ni site. Furthermore, it is noteworthy that the distance between Cu and Ni atoms in the four optimized structural models is around 2.5 Å, which is consistent with the measuring result in the HAADF-STEM. The charge distribution of the four structures shows that electrons accumulate more on Ni, and there is a substantial charge transfer between Cu and Ni and between the metal and the first coordination shell (Fig. 1b and Fig. S65). Different coordination structures have certain differences in the charge density of the metal center, which is the source of the difference in CO2 overall splitting performance. In addition, we calculate ΔG of each intermediate state where the ECR reaction takes place on the catalyst surface (Fig. 4c, Figs. S66 and S67). In general, the process of protonation of CO2 to *COOH on the catalyst surface in the ECR reaction is endothermic and needs to overcome the maximum ΔG. Therefore, the conversion from CO2 to *COOH (CO2→*COOH) is the rate determining step (RDS) of ECR reaction. Similarly, for OER, *OH→*O has the highest ΔG to overcome, indicating that *OH→*O is the RDS of OER. As expected, the order of ΔG for the formation of the key intermediate *COOH on the models is Cu/Ni–N2C2 (0.51 eV) < Cu/Ni–N2C3 (0.75 eV) < Cu/Ni–N4C2 (0.83 eV) < Cu/Ni–N2C4 (1.05 eV). In addition, the ΔG of *COOH on Cu/Ni–N2C2 (0.51 eV) is lower than Ni–NC (0.76 eV) and Cu–NC (0.70 eV). These results indicate that *COOH more readily forms on diatomic sample Cu/Ni–N2C2, leading to its excellent ECR performance. Moreover, the ΔG of *COOH to *CO transformation on Cu/Ni–N2C2 is smaller compared to other diatomic samples, indicating that *COOH to *CO transformation is easier for Cu/Ni–N2C2, which matched the above in-situ ATR-SEIRAS results. Moreover, ΔG calculations were conducted for each elementary reaction step of the HER side reaction (Figs. S68 and S69). Notably, the ΔG for *H generation on the Cu/Ni–N2C4 surface exceeds that of the other three structures, presenting a seeming contradiction with the electrocatalytic performance in ECR process. Considering that HER is the main competitive reaction, the difference between thermodynamic limiting potentials for CO2 reduction and H2 evolution (E L(CO2) − E L(H2)) of the four diatomic structures is compared (Fig. 4d). The selectivity of the structure to the ECR reaction can be intuitively reflected. As expected, the E L(CO2) − E L(H2) ordering of the four structures was Cu/Ni–N2C2 (0.22 V vs RHE) > Cu/Ni–N2C3 (0.21 V vs RHE) > Cu/Ni–N4C2 (0.18 V vs RHE) > Cu/Ni–N2C4 (0.16 V vs RHE), in alignment with the electrochemical test results. This revealed that with the reduction of coordination atoms around the metal, the selectivity of the material to the ECR reaction gradually increased, while the ECR and HER performance of Cu/Ni–N2C4 were poor compared with the other three diatomic materials. For OER, the *O on Cu/Ni–N2C2 has the lowest ΔG of generation, which is the source of its excellent performance (Fig. 4e and Figs. S70 and S71). The order of the maximum ΔG of the four materials is Cu/Ni–N2C2 (0.82 eV) < Cu/Ni–N2C3 (0.96 eV) < Cu/Ni–N4C2 (0.98 eV) < Cu/Ni–N2C4 (1.63 eV), and the ΔG of *O on Cu/Ni–N2C2 (0.82 eV) is lower than Ni–NC (1.13 eV) and Cu–NC (1.10 eV), which accords with the electrochemical test results above. The partial densities of state (pDOS) of Ni on diatomic structures were calculated to analyze the strength change between the metal and the adsorbent (Fig. 4f). With the transformation of N to C coordination around the metal, there is an observable shift in the d band center of Ni away from the Fermi level. And a reduction in the coordination number prompts the d band center to move closer to the Fermi level, indicating that the energy level of the anti-bonding orbital increases correspondingly. And it is more difficult for electrons to fill the anti-bonding orbital, which promotes the adsorption of the key intermediates *COOH and *O. Then the intrinsic performance of CO2 overall splitting reaction was improved. This result is ascribed to the regulation of the electronic structure of the Ni 3d orbital by the surrounding coordination atoms. To sum up, the different performance of CO2 overall splitting reaction in the configurations is ascribed to the interaction of Cu and Ni atoms and the regulation of the electronic structure of the metal active site by different coordination environments, thus affecting the d-band center position of the metal center and changing the adsorption ability of the metal to key intermediates. The ΔG of key intermediates at the Cu/Ni diatomic sites is lower than that at the Cu atomic sites and Ni atomic sites. And the transformation of N-coordination to C-coordination around the metal is not conducive to the reduction of ΔG for the formation of the key intermediates *COOH and *O. But on this basis, the reduction of the coordination number around the metal effectively decreases the ΔG associated with the RDS and improves the conversion ability of *COOH to *CO, thereby promoting the CO2 overall splitting reaction. 4 Conclusions In conclusion, this work successfully achieved precise and controllable construction of the coordination environment around diatomic metal materials by adjusting pyrolysis conditions of precursor materials. Among them, Cu/Ni–N2C2 showed high catalytic performance and stability for CO2 overall splitting reaction. The FECO is nearly 100% (98.4%) at low potential −0.6 V vs. RHE, and the OER overpotential in the neutral electrolyte is as low as 540 mV. Significantly, the FECO of Cu/Ni–N2C2 in the CO2 overall splitting is above 90% over −2.7 to −4.1 V of cell voltage. And Cu/Ni–N2C2 achieved long-term ECR stability of 110 h at −100 mA cm−2. Its performance is different from that of the other three structures and much better than that of the reported CO2 overall splitting catalyst. In-situ characterization and the DFT calculation revealed the source of the performance differences. The ΔG of key intermediates at the Cu/Ni diatomic sites is lower than that at the Cu atomic sites and Ni atomic sites. And the transition from N-coordination to C-coordination around the metal makes the Ni d-band center position shift upward, which is not conducive to the reduction of the ΔG for the formation of key intermediates *COOH and *O. On this basis, the decrease of coordination number around the metal can make the d-band center of Ni move closer to the Fermi level. By reducing the free energy barrier of the RDS of the ECR and OER processes, the conversion ability of *COOH to *CO is improved, thereby promoting the CO2 overall splitting reaction. This work presents high-quality insights into the correlation between heteronuclear diatomic coordination environment and electrocatalysis at molecular scale. coredata.dc:description: Designing the coordination environment of heteroatoms around metal sites and optimizing the electronic structure of diatomic metal sites remain significant challenges in achieving efficient CO2 overall splitting. Herein, we report four configurations (Cu/Ni–N4C2, Cu/Ni–N2C4, Cu/Ni–N2C3 and Cu/Ni–N2C2) constructed by precise regulation of the coordination environment around bimetallic atoms. Cu/Ni–N2C2 showed high performance in electrochemical CO2 reduction (ECR) and water oxidation evolution reaction (OER). In the electrochemical CO2 overall splitting reaction, it achieved a Faraday efficiency of CO (FECO) of 98.0% at a low cell voltage of −2.9 V, significantly higher than widely reported values. Moreover, the FECO is above 90% over −2.7 to −4.1 V of cell voltages. Cu/Ni–N2C2 achieved long-term ECR stability of 110 h at −100 mA cm−2. Mechanism studies revealed that the change of coordination environment around the diatomic pairs moves the d-band center of the Ni atom closer to the Fermi level, thereby modulating the adsorption capacity of the catalysts to the reaction intermediates *COOH and *O. This work presents valuable insights into the rational design of diatomic catalysts and elucidates the intricate structure-performance relationship in advancing electrochemical CO2 overall splitting technology and energy-conversion applications.
